back: Building internal products (templates, modules, pipelines, tooling) that let teams self-serve infrastructure/app delivery safely and consistently, reducing tickets and bespoke work.
A paved, recommended way to deliver a workload (repo template + CI/CD + IaC modules + security controls) that is fast by default and compliant by default.
Developers can provision what they need without filing tickets, using approved workflows (e.g., Terraform modules and pipelines) with automated controls.
Automated constraints that allow speed within safe bounds (policy checks at PR/plan/apply). They prevent risky configurations while keeping delivery flow moving.
Mandatory approval or centralized checkpoints before changes proceed. Useful for truly high-risk actions, but overuse creates queues and slows delivery.
Expressing governance rules in code so they’re versioned, testable, and automatically enforced (e.g., blocking public storage or requiring encryption).
A standardized cloud foundation (accounts/subscriptions/projects, networking, logging, identity, baseline policies) that teams deploy workloads into.
A repeatable way to create environments across teams/clouds using shared modules and workflows, reducing snowflakes and drift.
A long-lived credential stored somewhere (CI variables, scripts, config files) that remains valid until manually rotated, increasing compromise risk.
Credentials generated on demand with a short TTL and precise scope (often issued by a broker like Vault), reducing blast radius and rotation burden.
Short-lived credentials (minutes/hours) used for a task and then expiring automatically, limiting exposure if leaked.
Granting only the minimum permissions needed for a workload/job, reducing the impact of compromise or mistakes.
How much damage a compromise or misconfiguration can cause (data, systems, accounts). Ephemeral, scoped creds reduce blast radius.
Many unmanaged secrets/keys scattered across repos, pipelines, and teams—hard to audit, rotate, or revoke consistently.
CI jobs authenticate to the cloud by presenting an OIDC token; the cloud issues short-lived role credentials—no long-lived keys stored in CI.
An identity for a running workload (job, service, pipeline) that can obtain temporary credentials securely (often via OIDC), instead of using shared user keys.
A permission set that workloads can assume to get temporary credentials; central to replacing static access keys with short-lived access.
A system (e.g., Vault) that authenticates workloads and issues short-lived, policy-scoped credentials to downstream systems.
How long a token/credential is valid. Short TTLs reduce risk because stolen creds expire quickly.
Replacing credentials on a schedule or automatically. Dynamic/ephemeral approaches reduce the need for painful manual rotation.
When real infrastructure diverges from the declared configuration (e.g., manual changes in the console), increasing outages and audit findings.
Running meaningful workloads across more than one cloud provider (AWS + Azure, etc.), typically to address M&A, regulation, resilience, or vendor strategy.
Ready: portable patterns and skills to move if needed. Active-active: workloads running across clouds continuously—much higher complexity and cost.
How teams work: ownership, processes, controls, incentives, and tooling. In platform contexts: who builds/owns the platform, how teams consume it, and how change is governed.
Treat the platform as a product with roadmaps, user feedback, SLOs, and adoption goals—not as an ad-hoc ticket queue.
Percent of time services meet availability targets. Business link: protects revenue, brand trust, and reduces incident cost.
How often major incidents occur and how severe they are. Business link: fewer outages and less executive risk.
Average time to recover from incidents. Business link: shorter customer impact windows and lower operational cost.
Percent of deployments/changes that cause incidents or require rollback. Business link: safer velocity and reduced downtime.
Time from code committed/approved to running in production. Business link: faster delivery of features and responses to market/regulatory needs.
How often you deploy to production. Business link: more iterative delivery and quicker value realization (when paired with low failure rate).

front: KPI: Provisioning lead time (environment spin-up time)
back: Time to create a compliant environment (accounts/networking/cluster). Business link: reduces delivery friction and accelerates projects.
Ops/platform tickets and time spent on repetitive work. Business link: lowers operational cost and frees staff for higher-value work.
Cost per transaction/customer/workload unit. Business link: margin improvement and scalable growth.

front: KPI: Forecast accuracy / variance to budget
back: How close actual cloud spend is to forecast and budget. Business link: financial predictability and fewer spend surprises.
